content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is interesting because it is similar to a real-world tool (even if is is very simplified and performance considerations are not needed here.)
It might be on the harder side of "easy" just because of the quite long description, but if one follows the description very closely, the solution is straightforward.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ok for me!

Pros: I really like the real-world goal of making a diff tool.

Cons: Complex instructions for an easy puzzle.

Suggestion: Remove the configuration parameter value and always do BY_NUMBER or BY_CONTENT. The instructions can then be simpler.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and practical puzzle that can prove quite tricky to handle if the cases are not well-established. Intuitive and straightforward otherwise :)

Hey @poppu, I will gladly approve this contribution :) Do you have any plans to include the MOVE operation as we previously discussed? I.e.,

BY_CONTENT
2
A
B
2
B
A

As some people suggested, I moved this contribution from Clash of Code to easy Puzzle section.
Because it may not be easy to read and code this one in five minutes.

Also I did not find any move option so I just created a new puzzle and copy/paste values from the Clash of Code one.

Unfortunately, as you discovered, there isn't currently an option to directly move a contribution from one category to another, so copy-and-paste was indeed the only available workaround.

For anyone looking for the original version, you can find it here: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1349522bb6db741ff2175262f1b53c7463344e

Ah you are right. Now that it's a puzzle there is time to handle move operations.
Thanks for the reminder, I'll try to add it.
Good catch ;)
Thanks :)

Hello @User123,
MOVE operation is now included in the puzzle.
Feel free to give your feedback :)

Hey @poppu, sorry for the late reply. Thanks for including the MOVE operation :)

I have one main concern, namely, that the first rule applied to two files marked BY_CONTENT is: "two lines are considered the same if their contents are identical, regardless of their line numbers." This seems to conflict directly with the premise of the MOVE operation, since a MOVE operation depends on two lines with equal content but different line numbers.

It seems that I had missed this the first time round. Perhaps this wasn't meant to be an edge case to be handled, but rather, a misunderstanding of the text diff tool rules previously. What do you think?

Hello @User123,

I don't see any conflict here. 

When configuration is set BY_CONTENT it means you identify an instance of a line by its text content. So you can have a move operation when a line has same text content but is not at the same place in the revised file.

In the opposite, its not possible to get MOVE operation when configuration is set BY_NUMBER. Because you identify an instance of a line by its position inside the file. So lines at different positions will never be considered the same instance in such case.

Since lines are equal if their content is equal, wouldn't these pairs of lines be considered matched? Then there wouldn't be a need for the MOVE operation at all, since the remaining four operations (ADD, DELETE, CHANGE, MOVE) should only apply to unmatched lines.

Ok I got it, the description is a bit confusing.

I updated the description to make it less confuse. Tell me if it's ok or if there is still some explanation missing ?

Hey @poppu, sorry for the late reply. I see what you're trying to do, but I got a little bit confused at what "matched" and "equal" would now mean in each scenario. Perhaps it might be clearer to express the rules as steps?

The behaviour of the tool is defined as follows:
<<Step 1:>> The tool matches lines from the revised file to the ones in the original file, based on the configuration parameter value.
• If set to {{BY_NUMBER}}, lines are considered matched if they have the same line number, regardless of their contents.
• If set to {{BY_CONTENT}}, lines are considered matched if their contents are identical, regardless of their line numbers.
<<Step 2:>> The tool processes differences between matched lines, based on the configuration parameter value.
• If set to {{BY_NUMBER}}, the tool shall output {{CHANGE}} for each pair of matched lines with unequal content.
• If set to {{BY_CONTENT}}, the tool shall output {{MOVE}} for each pair of matched lines with unequal line numbers.
<<Step 3:>> The tool processes differences between unmatched lines, regardless of the configuration parameter value.
• The tool shall output {{DELETE}} for every unmatched line that exists only in the original file.
• The tool shall output {{ADD}} for every unmatched line that exists only in the revised file.

Hello @User123,

I agree that your description of the tool behavior using steps is clearer. I'll update it with your proposal.

Thanks for your feedback :)
Nice! One last thing, please specify that line numbers are 1-indexed; i.e., that the first line on each file has line number 1. Other than that the puzzle looks good to me :)

Ah well spotted !

Line numbers are now written in output in case of MOVE and they must match the ones in the tests. It is an important information.

Thanks again :)

To both @poppu and @User123:

Do "paired" and "unpaired" sound better than "matched" and "unmatched"? I find it a bit odd to describe two lines as matched while it's still possible for them to have differences.

Hello @5DN1L,

PersonaIly I prefer "match" and "unmatched". But I can change it if most people find it better.
@5DN1L I am ok with either term; the description of how lines are matched/paired is the most important.
Thank you both. Let's wait for others' feedback before changing anything.
